descriptionMD: A series of short videos on key business topics you can use to "kick off" a meeting
name: Meeting Starters at ITProTV
subtitle: Meeting Starters - ITProTV Studios

episodes.description: Developed through direct work with leaders of top companies and a research study of 10,000 high potential employees, this session talks about the seven characteristics of a leader that people would willingly follow.
episodes.title: Leadership
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.450
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.450 --> 00:00:08.402
>> Hi and welcome to BizPro.TV,
I'm your host Vicki Hall and

3
00:00:08.402 --> 00:00:11.257
I'm here with my good friend John Spence.

4
00:00:11.257 --> 00:00:13.985
Today, we're gonna talk
a lot about leadership and

5
00:00:13.985 --> 00:00:18.350
leadership is one of those topics that
is so important to any organization.

6
00:00:18.350 --> 00:00:21.264
But oftentimes,
we make it way too complex.

7
00:00:21.264 --> 00:00:26.231
John has taught leadership for over 20
years with thousands of individuals and

8
00:00:26.231 --> 00:00:31.214
he likes to keep things pretty simple for
us, so it's easy for us to understand.

9
00:00:31.214 --> 00:00:34.891
So today, we're gonna break it down,
make leadership simple.

10
00:00:34.891 --> 00:00:37.847
And I guess I just wanna start out,
John, by saying,

11
00:00:37.847 --> 00:00:41.791
in your experience over the last 20
years with all of the companies and

12
00:00:41.791 --> 00:00:46.196
all of the leadership leaders that you've
worked with, what are some of the key

13
00:00:46.196 --> 00:00:50.829
take-aways that we can help to keep things
simple when we think about leadership?

14
00:00:50.829 --> 00:00:52.459
>> Sure, Vicki.
Thank you.

15
00:00:52.459 --> 00:00:56.814
Well, actually what I did is rather than
try to give you a theory that I created by

16
00:00:56.814 --> 00:01:01.689
myself, I did a survey several years ago
to 10,000 high potential employees at top

17
00:01:01.689 --> 00:01:03.320
companies around the world.

18
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:06.916
These were the best of the best, the folks
that anyone would love to have in

19
00:01:06.916 --> 00:01:10.222
their company and I asked them a very
focused question which was what

20
00:01:10.222 --> 00:01:13.433
are the characteristics of a leader
you would willingly follow?

21
00:01:13.433 --> 00:01:15.783
Not famous leaders or iconic leaders, but

22
00:01:15.783 --> 00:01:18.784
who is the kind of a person
that you wanna come to work for

23
00:01:18.784 --> 00:01:22.712
everyday that you want as your leader and
they told me seven key things.

24
00:01:22.712 --> 00:01:27.072
They all happen to begin with C and
I'll got ahead and give you the first one,

25
00:01:27.072 --> 00:01:28.860
cuz it's the most important.

26
00:01:28.860 --> 00:01:33.312
The other ones you can sort of mix up,
but the first one is character and

27
00:01:33.312 --> 00:01:36.500
another word here would be integrity or
honesty.

28
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:40.866
Great research study by Kouzes and
Posner, I know you've studied them, too.

29
00:01:40.866 --> 00:01:44.550
They did a 30 year research study,
4 continents, 3 million respondents and

30
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:45.642
ask the same question.

31
00:01:45.642 --> 00:01:49.161
That's where I got the question is what
are the characteristics of a leader you

32
00:01:49.161 --> 00:01:50.342
would willingly follow?

33
00:01:50.342 --> 00:01:53.992
Four major answers and
the first one was honesty.

34
00:01:53.992 --> 00:01:57.740
89% of the people worldwide,
that's 3 decades, 4 continents,

35
00:01:57.740 --> 00:02:00.737
3 million respondents all
said that telling the truth,

36
00:02:00.737 --> 00:02:04.620
being honest is the single most important
thing they look for in a leader.

37
00:02:04.620 --> 00:02:06.676
The next one was forward-looking.

38
00:02:06.676 --> 00:02:10.412
Another word for that would be
visionary and a key idea here is,

39
00:02:10.412 --> 00:02:14.801
it's not just the CEO or the senior
management team that sets the vision.

40
00:02:14.801 --> 00:02:18.546
If one person follows you, just one,
you set the vision for the two of you.

41
00:02:18.546 --> 00:02:22.889
So, every leader at every level has
to be forward-looking or visionary.

42
00:02:22.889 --> 00:02:24.298
The next one was competent.

43
00:02:24.298 --> 00:02:28.340
You gotta be extremely good at what you
do and there's two areas of competence.

44
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:31.909
You gotta be good at your job, highly
competent that I like to use the word,

45
00:02:31.909 --> 00:02:35.322
towering confidence and you have to
be good at your leadership skills.

46
00:02:35.322 --> 00:02:38.761
And then the last of the major four was
inspiring and that doesn't mean that

47
00:02:38.761 --> 00:02:41.775
you've got to go rah, rah,
sis boom, bah and be a cheerleader.

48
00:02:41.775 --> 00:02:43.831
What it means is that
if you're not inspired,

49
00:02:43.831 --> 00:02:45.845
don't expect anyone else
on your team to be.

50
00:02:45.845 --> 00:02:49.280
You've got to be passionate,
committed, excited,

51
00:02:49.280 --> 00:02:51.529
inspired in order to be inspiring.

52
00:02:51.529 --> 00:02:56.310
So, those four all fit up under
that first C of character.

53
00:02:56.310 --> 00:02:58.599
>> Yeah, and character is so important and

54
00:02:58.599 --> 00:03:02.787
what you said about being willing to
follow a leader, I think that is key.

55
00:03:02.787 --> 00:03:06.734
Other things to consider in leadership
that keep it simple for us?

56
00:03:06.734 --> 00:03:09.191
>> Yeah, well,
we'll go through the other C's.

57
00:03:09.191 --> 00:03:12.460
So, the character's first and
it's first among all of them.

58
00:03:12.460 --> 00:03:17.260
The next one that I like is courage and
what they told me here is I

59
00:03:17.260 --> 00:03:22.800
expect my leader to be courageous, to take
big, bold risks, to take tough decisions,

60
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:27.400
but what I really want is a leader who
is courageous enough to be vulnerable.

61
00:03:27.400 --> 00:03:31.140
To admit, they don't have all
the answers to ask for help.

62
00:03:31.140 --> 00:03:35.447
Unbelievably important thing in being an
effective leader is having the courage and

63
00:03:35.447 --> 00:03:37.095
vulnerability to ask for help.

64
00:03:37.095 --> 00:03:39.956
Now this doesn't mean you should be
sitting in the corner like, yeah,

65
00:03:39.956 --> 00:03:40.963
I don't know what to do.

66
00:03:40.963 --> 00:03:45.934
90% of the time you're courageous,
you're bold, you're a risk taker, but 10%

67
00:03:45.934 --> 00:03:50.508
of the time when you feel overwhelmed you
admit it, when you don't have the answer

68
00:03:50.508 --> 00:03:55.045
you admit it and you show people that
you're courageous enough to be authentic.

69
00:03:55.045 --> 00:03:59.879
>> Courage, I've seen courage in action
and I've seen the opposite of courage in

70
00:03:59.879 --> 00:04:04.441
action and I can clearly see how that is
a huge trait to being a great leader.

71
00:04:04.441 --> 00:04:07.142
What's the next C that we can think about?

72
00:04:07.142 --> 00:04:10.966
>> This C is one that we mentioned
earlier from Kouzes and Posner, but

73
00:04:10.966 --> 00:04:15.628
it's one that's essential in building
trust and respect which is confidence.

74
00:04:15.628 --> 00:04:19.837
And the idea here is that you've got to be
really, really, really good at your job

75
00:04:19.837 --> 00:04:23.758
and really good at your leadership
skills and here's what I share with you.

76
00:04:23.758 --> 00:04:25.559
There's no excuses not to be.

77
00:04:25.559 --> 00:04:29.639
If you're going to be a leader, you've got
to set the example of a being life long

78
00:04:29.639 --> 00:04:33.539
learner and never in the history of
humankind has there been more information

79
00:04:33.539 --> 00:04:35.352
available for free than right now.

80
00:04:35.352 --> 00:04:40.566
So there's no excuses, you should be
watching TED Talks and Big Think and

81
00:04:40.566 --> 00:04:45.108
YouTube videos and listening to
iTunes Podcasts and reading and

82
00:04:45.108 --> 00:04:50.089
reading different magazine and
all those ways to invest in yourself.

83
00:04:50.089 --> 00:04:53.876
Because the more information you have
access to, the more you can help other

84
00:04:53.876 --> 00:04:57.500
people, the more respected you will
be as a leader for your competence.

85
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.922
And if you wanna have a great team and
a great company, having people that

86
00:05:00.922 --> 00:05:04.738
are highly competent, focused and always
getting better every day, what I call

87
00:05:04.738 --> 00:05:08.014
personal [INAUDIBLE] is fundamental
to building your great company.

88
00:05:08.014 --> 00:05:12.477
And if the leader isn't highly competent
in setting that example no one else will

89
00:05:12.477 --> 00:05:13.142
follow it.

90
00:05:13.142 --> 00:05:17.498
>> Yeah, and going back to being a leader
that you wanna follow, I can completely

91
00:05:17.498 --> 00:05:22.590
understand how competence is one of
those things that if you don't have it.

92
00:05:22.590 --> 00:05:25.260
I mean, people are definitely not
going to respect you as a leader and

93
00:05:25.260 --> 00:05:28.030
that's probably a huge component as well.

94
00:05:28.030 --> 00:05:30.020
What's another one,
John that we can think of?

95
00:05:30.020 --> 00:05:32.324
>> The next C is communication.

96
00:05:32.324 --> 00:05:34.671
And again,
when you hear all these, remember,

97
00:05:34.671 --> 00:05:36.628
this isn't a theory that I came up with.

98
00:05:36.628 --> 00:05:40.694
Although I've been studying leadership,
read hundreds of books on it,

99
00:05:40.694 --> 00:05:42.274
lead a couple of companies.

100
00:05:42.274 --> 00:05:46.320
This is what those 10,000 high
potential employees told me and

101
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:49.390
what they said around
communication was of course,

102
00:05:49.390 --> 00:05:53.155
I expect my leader to be able to
stand up and explain the vision and

103
00:05:53.155 --> 00:05:56.321
give a motivating talk and
give clear expectations.

104
00:05:56.321 --> 00:05:57.346
But what I really,

105
00:05:57.346 --> 00:06:02.340
really want from my leader is someone who
asks great questions and listens intently.

106
00:06:02.340 --> 00:06:04.080
Someone's who curious.

107
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:07.179
I've hired good people,
they're on my team, I'm leading this team.

108
00:06:07.179 --> 00:06:10.311
Why in the world wouldn't I be
excited about asking them questions,

109
00:06:10.311 --> 00:06:13.443
trying to get their opinion,
they're feedback, they're input.

110
00:06:13.443 --> 00:06:17.306
So you want a leader that's very curious,
constantly asking questions.

111
00:06:17.306 --> 00:06:20.537
And then when someone gives them
the answer, they're an intense listener.

112
00:06:20.537 --> 00:06:21.965
They're using great body language.

113
00:06:21.965 --> 00:06:22.593
They're focused.

114
00:06:22.593 --> 00:06:23.768
They're taking notes.

115
00:06:23.768 --> 00:06:24.494
They're listening.

116
00:06:24.494 --> 00:06:25.613
They're trying to understand.

117
00:06:25.613 --> 00:06:29.188
They're asking more questions and
the other key thing is once they've asked

118
00:06:29.188 --> 00:06:32.928
the question, and listened, and written
notes that they actually apply some of

119
00:06:32.928 --> 00:06:35.640
the things that they've been
told by their team members.

120
00:06:35.640 --> 00:06:40.073
So lots of open, honest,
robust, high trust, high candor,

121
00:06:40.073 --> 00:06:42.175
communication is critical.

122
00:06:42.175 --> 00:06:43.283
Asking great questions and

123
00:06:43.283 --> 00:06:45.793
listening is what they told me
they wanted from their leader.

124
00:06:45.793 --> 00:06:49.350
>> Yeah, I can see how these are kind
of building upon each other.

125
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:53.600
Because if a leader doesn't have character
and their communicating with you, maybe in

126
00:06:53.600 --> 00:06:57.320
a way that they think is effective,
you're gonna see right through that.

127
00:06:57.320 --> 00:07:00.860
So I can see how these are just
building one on top of the other, but

128
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:02.560
I think there's more, John.

129
00:07:02.560 --> 00:07:05.311
>> Yep, the next one is collaboration.

130
00:07:05.311 --> 00:07:09.364
And again, here's what the folks told
me is I understand you're my leader.

131
00:07:09.364 --> 00:07:11.595
I know you're my boss, I got that.

132
00:07:11.595 --> 00:07:15.413
You've got more seniority, rank and
title, but don't lord that over me.

133
00:07:15.413 --> 00:07:19.650
If every now and then you gotta say, do
this, because I'm you're boss, I'm fine.

134
00:07:19.650 --> 00:07:25.158
But the rest of the time, I wanna see you
as a team player as a partner and a peer.

135
00:07:25.158 --> 00:07:27.269
I wanna see my leader
roll up their sleeves.

136
00:07:27.269 --> 00:07:29.229
Get in there shoulder to shoulder with us.

137
00:07:29.229 --> 00:07:30.399
Work as part of the team.

138
00:07:30.399 --> 00:07:34.520
Do the work and communicate, and
work with us as a peer as a partner.

139
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:38.228
And then if you say,
do it, because I told you.

140
00:07:38.228 --> 00:07:39.459
Do it, because I'm your manager.

141
00:07:39.459 --> 00:07:40.996
Do it, because I own the company.

142
00:07:40.996 --> 00:07:42.363
I'll handle that.

143
00:07:42.363 --> 00:07:45.120
The reverse is if you constantly
lead from that command and

144
00:07:45.120 --> 00:07:49.059
control thing that ain't gonna work and
your best people will leave immediately,

145
00:07:49.059 --> 00:07:52.343
because they get frustrated and
they don't want to be lead that way.

146
00:07:52.343 --> 00:07:54.666
>> Yeah, we talk about teamwork so often.

147
00:07:54.666 --> 00:07:59.669
And oftentimes, we miss the whole
leadership part of teamwork.

148
00:07:59.669 --> 00:08:04.641
And from what you're saying, collaboration
as a leader really can play into whether

149
00:08:04.641 --> 00:08:06.447
or not the team is successful.

150
00:08:06.447 --> 00:08:10.638
>> Absolutely and then part of it too is
that we've got a different make up of

151
00:08:10.638 --> 00:08:12.921
the people in the workforce right now.

152
00:08:12.921 --> 00:08:14.361
As the millennials come in and

153
00:08:14.361 --> 00:08:17.931
they're gonna be the largest section
of workers over the next ten years,

154
00:08:17.931 --> 00:08:22.170
the baby boomers and gen X are moving out,
retiring, going to other places.

155
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:26.790
You're gonna look for a leader that is
if they're not a team member, if they

156
00:08:26.790 --> 00:08:30.880
don't work well with folks, if they don't
treat other people with respect and

157
00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:32.650
respect their information, their ideas,

158
00:08:32.650 --> 00:08:37.290
their experience, their suggestions,
you can't actually build a cohesive team.

159
00:08:37.290 --> 00:08:42.376
Another big idea with the millennials
is the next C, which is compassion.

160
00:08:42.376 --> 00:08:43.571
I'm 52 years old.

161
00:08:43.571 --> 00:08:45.392
When I grew up, when my boss said, jump.

162
00:08:45.392 --> 00:08:47.100
I said, how high, sir?

163
00:08:47.100 --> 00:08:49.086
It was all command and control, all men.

164
00:08:49.086 --> 00:08:53.414
Now it's changed and employees today,
want more flexibility.

165
00:08:53.414 --> 00:08:56.806
They want more of say in their outcome,
they want you to be compassionate and

166
00:08:56.806 --> 00:08:57.659
understand that.

167
00:08:57.659 --> 00:09:00.422
Yes, this is my job, but I have other
things that are just as important to me.

168
00:09:00.422 --> 00:09:03.012
My family, my hobbies, my faith.

169
00:09:03.012 --> 00:09:05.386
I play on a sports team,
whatever it might be.

170
00:09:05.386 --> 00:09:08.220
I'll give you my 40,
maybe my 50 hours a week.

171
00:09:08.220 --> 00:09:11.843
But after that, I'm out of here and I'm
going home to spend time with my friends,

172
00:09:11.843 --> 00:09:13.996
my family to go surfing,
whatever it might be and

173
00:09:13.996 --> 00:09:16.322
it's not that they don't
have a strong work ethic.

174
00:09:16.322 --> 00:09:20.087
It's they have a different
value system that says,

175
00:09:20.087 --> 00:09:22.833
I need to be felt like I'm important.

176
00:09:22.833 --> 00:09:24.137
I do important work.

177
00:09:24.137 --> 00:09:25.619
I'm making a difference in the world.

178
00:09:25.619 --> 00:09:28.879
I'm contributing to the company,
title isn't that important.

179
00:09:28.879 --> 00:09:32.250
They want fair pay, but
it isn't all about money.

180
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:35.380
So, they need a leader who's
compassionate enough to understand

181
00:09:35.380 --> 00:09:38.260
that this job isn't their whole life.

182
00:09:38.260 --> 00:09:40.697
That their really focused on
other parts of their life and

183
00:09:40.697 --> 00:09:42.981
they want to feel good while
they're in the company,

184
00:09:42.981 --> 00:09:45.907
that the leader truly cares about them and
has compassion for them.

185
00:09:45.907 --> 00:09:49.609
>> And it makes a huge difference is you
work for somebody who cares about you.

186
00:09:49.609 --> 00:09:53.857
It definitely makes a big difference
in the leadership style of that leader.

187
00:09:53.857 --> 00:09:56.503
Is there a final C that you
wanna share with us today, John?

188
00:09:56.503 --> 00:10:00.189
>> Yeah, and Vicky, I'll touch on
what you just said is, it's very,

189
00:10:00.189 --> 00:10:03.752
very hard to be inspired, passionate,
committed and excited for

190
00:10:03.752 --> 00:10:06.571
a leader that isn't and
doesn't treat you fairly.

191
00:10:06.571 --> 00:10:12.087
Interesting piece of research shows that
the number one factor in highly engaged,

192
00:10:12.087 --> 00:10:17.234
satisfied and loyal customers is engaged,
satisfied and loyal employees.

193
00:10:17.234 --> 00:10:20.860
Another phrase I love to use here is the
customer's experience will never exceed

194
00:10:20.860 --> 00:10:22.257
the employee's experience.

195
00:10:22.257 --> 00:10:24.579
So if the employee doesn't
have a leader they admire,

196
00:10:24.579 --> 00:10:26.098
there isn't good communication.

197
00:10:26.098 --> 00:10:29.919
They're not treated with compassion,
you're not gonna see them do that for

198
00:10:29.919 --> 00:10:33.289
your customers which typically
runs to a thing called bankruptcy.

199
00:10:33.289 --> 00:10:37.850
Now if you've done the other six things
as well and you've become a good leader,

200
00:10:37.850 --> 00:10:39.268
you've got a good team.

201
00:10:39.268 --> 00:10:41.830
You're building a successful
company you're growing.

202
00:10:41.830 --> 00:10:46.221
The seventh C is contribution and
this is where the leader says,

203
00:10:46.221 --> 00:10:51.038
I'm gonna leave a legacy that I'm
gonna make long-term decisions.

204
00:10:51.038 --> 00:10:55.574
In America, at least,
we run on a very tight schedule of meeting

205
00:10:55.574 --> 00:10:59.109
quarterly goals or
meeting Wall Street demands.

206
00:10:59.109 --> 00:11:03.821
And oftentimes, our leaders, unfortunately
make very short-term decisions, but

207
00:11:03.821 --> 00:11:07.369
the best leaders and I see leaders
in other countries like Japan,

208
00:11:07.369 --> 00:11:12.624
where they make 10, 15, 20-year horizons
to allow them to make 20-year decisions.

209
00:11:12.624 --> 00:11:13.972
So as contribution goes,

210
00:11:13.972 --> 00:11:18.720
it's what I call planting the seeds of
trees under which you may never sit.

211
00:11:18.720 --> 00:11:19.836
Giving back to your community.

212
00:11:19.836 --> 00:11:21.384
Building a legacy of leadership.

213
00:11:21.384 --> 00:11:25.363
Creating other leaders and taking
the resources, and the authority, and

214
00:11:25.363 --> 00:11:29.470
the respect that you've earned by doing
the first six exceedingly well, and

215
00:11:29.470 --> 00:11:31.250
becoming a great leader.

216
00:11:31.250 --> 00:11:35.996
And then giving back as a servant leader
and leaving the organization better than

217
00:11:35.996 --> 00:11:39.853
you found it and better not just for
a few years, but for decades.

218
00:11:39.853 --> 00:11:44.299
>> Yeah, so John these seven Cs that you
just mentioned are very thorough, but

219
00:11:44.299 --> 00:11:47.644
keep things simple when we
wanna talk about leadership.

220
00:11:47.644 --> 00:11:50.282
Are there any final thoughts
that you had on leadership

221
00:11:50.282 --> 00:11:52.064
before we wrap up today's session?

222
00:11:52.064 --> 00:11:55.378
>> Yeah, I think the most important
thing to remember here is to be a great

223
00:11:55.378 --> 00:11:58.421
leader of others, you must first
be a great leader of yourself.

224
00:11:58.421 --> 00:12:02.193
So my recommendation is to think about
the seven that I've shared with you and

225
00:12:02.193 --> 00:12:05.908
then look at other things that you've had,
other influences you've had,

226
00:12:05.908 --> 00:12:07.434
leaders you've worked with.

227
00:12:07.434 --> 00:12:08.780
Good leaders, bad leaders.

228
00:12:08.780 --> 00:12:12.383
What you've learned from them,
your own personal value system and

229
00:12:12.383 --> 00:12:16.301
work on creating what I call your own
personal philosophy of leadership or

230
00:12:16.301 --> 00:12:20.283
your own personal leadership competency
model where you've got a written

231
00:12:20.283 --> 00:12:24.322
list of the key things that you wanna do
to be the kind of leader you wanna be and

232
00:12:24.322 --> 00:12:28.019
leave the kind of leadership legacy
you've always wanted to leave.

233
00:12:28.019 --> 00:12:31.811
And when you've got that, you can use it
as a touchstone for every day when you go

234
00:12:31.811 --> 00:12:35.321
in the office, every day you go to work,
to how you wanna act and behave and

235
00:12:35.321 --> 00:12:38.964
impact the other people in your
organization as a highly effective leader.

236
00:12:38.964 --> 00:12:41.899
>> So John, thank you for
that recap of the seven Cs of leadership.

237
00:12:41.899 --> 00:12:47.449
As always, you kept things simple on
a topic that can often be way too complex.

238
00:12:47.449 --> 00:12:50.336
So for BizPro.TV, I'm Vicky Hall.

239
00:12:50.336 --> 00:12:51.946

240
